reviews.reviewTitle: BAD SMELL + SO MUCH PLASTIC INSIDE
reviews.reviewText: Super cute but had a bad smell. Also, what I got was defective, the lid popped off while I was pouring and the steam burned my hand. Also, there's much more plastic, actually, soooo much more plastic that touches the water in that design. The customer photos don't represent it well.

Love this! I have mixed feelings about the spout. It's very wide which is heat when pouring quickly, but you're more apt to spill. But this is the only electric teapot I could find that looks like a teapot and not an ugly carafe. I had a Cuisinart one that died and was discontinued, so I'm happy to have found this one. The short cord doesn't bother me as I park it on my kitchen countertop permanently (I use it multiple times a day), which is also why I wanted a sleek looking teapot

Really pleased with this Kettle! I spent days with it in and out of my cart choosing between this model and some more expensive ($99-$150) electric kettles with more bells and whistles and I am happy that I chose this one. It is simple, easy to use, heats up water super fast, and just does the job well without having excess beeping/ buttons that I just don't need. If you are looking for a simple way to boil water without having many options about temperature, etc, then this would be perfect for you.
Also, It is really pretty on our countertops and I love the color!

This is a solid and serviceable electric kettle that makes enough hot water for a pot of tea or two large mugs. It wide lid make for easy de-scaling, that with it short wide design let it fit under most taps. What little plastic used on the kettle itself, is well place: A plastic knuckle guard under the lid handle protect the hand. A plastic spout screen frame, could be metal but would over time mineral lock in place, works well. Held up well so far, a couple of months, and we make a lot of tea.

I should have listened to other negative reviewers! This kettle is terribly designed for these reasons: the PLASTIC filter is submerged in the water so when the water boils guess what? You are boiling the plastic and everything that leaches from the plastic goes straight into your water! And there is a terrible chemical smell that lingers even when not in use. Next, the stainless steel handle of both the lid and kettle get hot when boiling a couple batches of water in a row. I guess that wasn't important to KitchenAid. This kettle was designed for looks not for function and I was a sucker :-(
I'm going back to the Breville tea kettle which worked 3 years for me but finally gave out. I thought I could save a few dollars and get a snazzy new look but it definitely wasn't worth it. Can't return it soon enough! Thank you Amazon Prime for great return policy!

reviews.reviewTitle: Loved it, until a coating started flaking off into the water after only 7 days.
reviews.reviewText: I really wanted to love this kettle. In fact, I do love it aesthetically, that's why I was willing to pay $80 for it when there are perfectly good kettles for much less. I even stuck with it when I realized it gave the water an extremely metallic taste. I boiled pot after pot of water trying to get the metallic taste to go away, and after a week, it was much improved. But then, last night, I realized the entire bottom coating (I didn't realize there was a coating) was flaking off on the inside of the kettle. I hadn't looked into it for a couple of days, so now I'm wondering how many of these big flakes I swallowed. Yuck! I only had this kettle a week before whatever the coating was began flaking off. It's hard and brittle. And the only thing I've boiled in it is water, so I know it's not any kind of film or residue from a liquid. Too bad. The search for a cute kettle is back on.

This is a very sleek-looking kettle. It's good-looking enough that I leave it out on my office shelf rather than stow it away when I'm not using it.

It has enough capacity for two full mugs with a little extra. I like that it has an automatic turn-off when the water reaches a boil, but I do wish it had a 'keep warm' feature. My only other complaint is that the cord is very short.

I'm happy with my purchase.

reviews.reviewTitle: Attractive small kettle - but metal gets hot
reviews.reviewText: I like the shape of this, which is bit like a stove-top kettle. It is smaller in real life than I anticipated, but it does fine for everyday tasks like tea-making and filling up for saucepans. The only negative is that the body of the kettle gets burning hot (the handle seems to still be touchable). This seems a major design flaw. I went for an electric kettle because I thought it would be safer than having the gas on around a young baby, but now I am reconsidering. However, now that I know this, I am just extra careful, so I think it will be alright.
Love this kettle! The bottom doesn't get hot, so I can set it on any surface, after its boiled. I'm so happy KitchenAid finally came out with more Pistachio colored products to go with my mixer.

reviews.reviewTitle: Well Built, but Plastic, Plastic, Plastic...
reviews.reviewText: I found nothing wrong with the construction of the kettle, but I did see way more plastic on the interior than I hoped. I actually hoped on having zero plastic on the interior. That was not the case. At this point, I don't believe there is such a thing as a plastic-free electric kettle. I've spent more hours searching than I can remember.

reviews.reviewTitle: Although I like the size and the style
reviews.reviewText:
I bought this to replace my Cuisinart electric kettle, which is not made anymore. I wanted a stainless steel "kettle-looking" style. I have had this for about 6 months. Although I like the size and the style, it is far too powerful. I can't walk away from it because if I leave it, it mists the whole underneath of my kitchen cabinets. I should have realized that it was going to be powerful when I saw the cord which is very heavy duty with a three prong plug.
The reason I like an electric kettle is so that I can put the water on, walk away and do other things while the water was heating and have it turn off automatically. If you leave this one, half the water boils out. The water comes out scalding hot and impossible to drink if I make tea. I always have to put an ice cube in it. This kettle is overkill. I now have to stand by it while it's heating and take it off the carriage before its starts misting all over the place.

Also, the color isn't an exact match with the Pistachio of the mixer. I bought it on sale for $50 and I still feel like I greatly over paid.

reviews.reviewTitle: Seams and plastic parts contacts water and steam (which falls back into the water)
reviews.reviewText:
I have a whistling (sort of) Kitchen Aid teakettle. Even though the whistle is anemic if you are in another room, I do like my KA whistling teakettle because NOTHING except seamless enamel coating contacts water or steam. The completely SEAMLESS interior enamel even coats screws & such.

THIS kettle is NOTHING like that! It has interior seams (which allow water into the seams to contact solder or who knows what).

This kettle is neither seamless nor coated with enamel inside - it is metal (Chinese "stainless" steel - which never is) and PLASTIC.

After liking my KA whistling kettle so much (except for the poor excuse for a whistle), I'm extremely disappointed with this kettle. I like the APPEARANCE very much, but cannot use it because of the design of the interior.

I'm wondering WHY the temperature cannot be controlled from inside the base underneath a kettle that has a seamless interior surface (American glass, enamel, aluminum, or 316L STAINLESS steel)? I do NOT trust Chinese metal, glass, or any other material to provide safety from metal toxins. The Chinese have proven that they will NOT stick to specifications (money always before people) and that they have NO regard for life (remember when they sent us contaminated baby products? (among many other things)). Materials like 304 "stainless" steel is usually used in these products and is less corrosion resistant and prone to pitting. Contaminants can be introduced into the metal material (not to mention the plastics). Even the glass electric teakettles have a metal bottom intruding INTO the glass interior, with, of course, a seam between the different materials. Below the seam, where the water can go?? Solder and who knows what else can contact the water.

reviews.reviewTitle: As every other kettle, full of plastic.
reviews.reviewText:
Well, everything about this kettle is superb in terms of quality, looks, and speed of boiling water. But, as with every other electric kettle I've come across it is for some absolutely unknown reason full of plastic inside. Can any company just make a good electric teat kettle with no plastic parts inside? Is it that hard?

Another review states you can remove the plastic filter. Yeah, and? What do you do with the plastic base where the filter goes solidly attached to the kettle? Break it off? I'm not willing to risk it. You may remove the plastic filter but not the base so it's no good.

If leeching plastic isn't a big concern for you with respect to the tea kettles this is a great electric kettle, though. I'm sticking within my 100% stainless steel (inside and out with no plastic anywhere) stove top kettle for now.

reviews.reviewTitle: Good for your Fallout Vault. Not great otherwise.
reviews.reviewText:
This electric kettle boils water. It does this fairly well, and fairly quickly. What it does not do is make a great deal of sense, from a design perspective.

Others have noted that it's hard to clean, which is true. Not only do the shape of the kettle, the size and position of the lid (directly beneath the handle), and the unusual internal components make the thing hard to clean; but mine additionally has a constant layer of gritty sediment, despite the fact that I use filtered water exclusively. It may be limescale, it may be something else, but it's constantly sloshing around in there, only kept out of my tea by the cheap plastic strainer attached to the inside of the kettle.

The kettle is certainly beautiful, and if your only concern is creating a nice mid-century Fallout Vault kitchen, then you can't do much better than this. But it feels cheap, which others have also mentioned. There's a lot of plastic, including inside, where it's in near-constant contact with the watter you boil. The shiny chrome handle is all plastic, and the on/off switch is too. Worst of all, the switch is connected to the unit by the flimsiest of plastic arms. It feels spindly and delicate every time I use it, and I worry that one day I'll absently apply just a little too much pressure with my terrifying Hulk hands and break the switch right off.

I received mine as a gift, and I've had it for about 4 months. Already the paint is starting to chip on the exterior of the kettle, for no apparent reason. Maybe this is a Brave Little Toaster kind of scenario, and my appliances come to life when I'm out of the house and wage gladiatorial combat in the darkened kitchen arena. More likely, this thing is built for looks and looks alone.

Edit: Decided to give it back a star because, at the end of the day, it performs its primary function well. I'm expecting it not to hold up, but for now it's working fine despite my gripes.

reviews.reviewTitle: Stylish and efficient, but interior contains some plastic parts
reviews.reviewText:
I received this KitchenAid KEK1222SX electric kettle from Amazon Vine for an honest review. Here’s my take on it.

It’s a nice size for countertop use and very stylish with its brushed stainless finish. It holds a little over one quart of water and has an LED on/off switch. (The LED lights up when the water is heating.) The kettle moves a full 360 degrees on its heating base unit, lifts completely off the base to fill vessel and to pour water out. The cord is short and heavy duty as a heating cord should be. Water heats in about five minutes with the 1500 watt heating element.

A smooth aluminum handle is attached to the kettle with an insulator between metal parts so the handle gets warm but not hot. A lime scale filter, or shield, traps hard water lime and can be cleaned to maintain good function of the kettle.

I found both looks and performance to be excellent, however, if you want a completely plastic-free electric kettle, this one isn’t for you. While the shield may be removable, the bracket (also plastic) is not, and if this is a problem, water pours over this plastic when pouring out the contents. Finally, there is no window or mark to gauge water level so one must measure the water with a measuring cup. Not a problem for me because I use a Melitta pour-over ceramic cone and have to measure the amount of water anyway.

Seems well made, but as previously mentioned, if you don’t wish to have boiling water poured over plastic that may or may not be BPA-free, you might want to choose another brand.

I asked for and received the stainless steel one for Christmas. What a great gift! It's the perfect size for two people. Doesn't take up much counter space, beautiful design, heats up much faster than a stove top one and I love the auto shut off! I've never had an electric teapot before but we're big tea drinkers, so this is a great addition to our kitchen!

We purchased this three years ago in blue , and it has formally died now. We have enjoyed it in that time, and it heats water quickly and the only complaint is that the paint scratches off quite easily. But I am definitely feeling nostalgic for my parents generation of small appliances, where items of this cost would last 15 years, not three. Kitchen Aid could improve.

reviews.reviewTitle: Love it and now need to replace it
reviews.reviewText: I’ve had this kettle for almost 3yrs and going to buy another one. We use it multiple times a day so it gets used a lot and now is peeling and chipped. I love the color as I have other kitchenaid items this color. I only wish they made other electric kettles in this color as I think a bigger size might be good but this one works well.

reviews.reviewTitle: Easy and fast to use- Boils water!
reviews.reviewText:
This KitchenAid kettle is attractive in the brushed stainless, with clean lines. It is very simple to use: you simply lift off the top, insert water, replace the top, place it on its base, and flip the switch to "ON." Roughly 4 minutes later, you'll have boiling water (using 32oz of 74 degree water to start with). Unlike some other kettles, this one clicks off very soon after reaching the boil point, saving a small amount of power. It uses 1500 watts of power, so be careful not to use another high power appliance on the same circuit while heating water. Pouring is easy and drip-less.

Possible drawbacks: There are no water temperature settings, and no external water level indicator (there is an internal MAX level indicator). It does not have a keep warm function, and it doesn't tell you when it is done except for the noise of the "on" switch popping up. There is a piece of plastic inside holding a lime scale filter that will be in the hot water if you boil more than 16 oz at a time. Despite its squat design, the kettle is about 10.5" tall, due to the handle perched on top. It holds a maximum of 42oz of water at a time.

I got this as a Christmas gift, so I've been using daily for about 4 months at the time of this review. Love this kettle. There are reviews about plastic being an issue, and unless you boil a very small amount of water it's true that the water will be touching some plastic. For me, it's not a huge concern, as I've eliminated all other plastics from my food storage and it's near impossible to find a kettle that doesn't have any plastic. That issue aside, it's very stylish, simple and works great.

reviews.reviewTitle: Get rid of the plastic KitchenAid!
reviews.reviewText: I'll be honest and tell you that I wish that as much effort as they did to make this Kettle look so sleek and high quality with all the stainless steel, I wish they had gotten rid of all the plastic inside. The kettle itself heats fast, rotates perfectly on its base, looks sleek and has a removable filter. You can remove the filter but the plastic piece housing the filter cannot be removed and that really bothers me. KitchenAid has not even offered any assurances that it is BPA free and I'm sincerely hoping it is, but I feel like this would be a 5 star Kettle if not for that plastic. Another gripe I have is that most Kettles have a water marking indicator and this one as you can see has none. Other than that, it works great and looks very sleek!
Good electric kettle. Highly recommended and does not take up a lot of space on counter

reviews.reviewTitle: Worked for a year now it leaks
reviews.reviewText: Kettle is attractive and worked great, but started leaking after 1 1/2 years. Compared to my Breville, which lasted 4+ years before having issues.

I enjoy drinking tea, and so am always looking for a way to heat water quickly. I have a tea kettle for the stove top, but it takes a while to bring a kettle of tea water to a boil. So, I was excited to get the chance to try this KitchenAid electric kettle.

I am very impressed. The kettle makes a pot of boiling water really fast. I like the fact that the handle remains cool to the touch, so after the water boils, you can directly hold the handle to pour the water. The water pours from the spout nicely, without running back up the spout . . . a problem I have had with other products.

We have really hard water where I live, and I have found that products like this last longer if you only use RO or bottled water, so I will not be using tap water in this unit. I want it to last.

A great product that looks good on the cabinet.

reviews.reviewTitle: As with all kitchenaid appliances I"ve used the quality is there and the speed/ease of use is great!!
reviews.reviewText: This kettle is top notch!!! As with all kitchenaid appliances I"ve used the quality is there and the speed/ease of use is great!!!
So so cute!
The perfect kettle for a small kitchen. Easy to operate. Works great. Could not be happier.

reviews.reviewTitle: I have had this for over a year and love the look of it
reviews.reviewText: I have had this for over a year and love the look of it. I wish it held more water. I noticed this morning when I opened it to fill with water it had rust inside the bottom. If you buy this make sure you dry it after every use.

reviews.reviewTitle: So far so good, lhas internal filter but no exterior water level indicator
reviews.reviewText: This kettle boils FAST, in about 4 minutes over a full quart of water is at a rapid boil. Don't be like McDonald's and pour the hot water in your lap, they aren't going to pay! Serilously though, be careful not to use several high wattage appliances at the same time, say a microwave, a fridge AND this water kettle, it may trip the circuit breaker (been there, done that.) All in all I love this water kettle, I just miss the exterior water indicator.

reviews.reviewTitle: But I really so no reason that a well-designed kettle in this price range should not be double-wall.
reviews.reviewText: But I really so no reason that a well-designed kettle in this price range should not be double-wall. In addition, my previous kettles heated their full pots in 2 minutes or less, not the 4 minutes this one takes.
I thought this was super retro so I got it. It heats up water fast so that i don't have to wait to make my coffee. It is important I get hot water fast and this kettle does the trick.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great design but plastic interior is a huge downside
reviews.reviewText: I enjoy the retro kettle form and general design but as others have pointed out, the plastic in the boiling container really doesn't need to be there and potentially imparts toxins into the water as it boils. On the plus side, it's relatively fast, pours without dripping and it's easy to clean but is fairly expensive compared with similar alternatives.

reviews.reviewTitle: After nine months, still smelling plastic...
reviews.reviewText: I bought this kettle at the end of last year. I loved that the design and it heats up water just fine. My problem is with the large plastic filter holder thing inside. After nine plus months of daily use, the water still smells like plastic. Why would anyone make such a nice thing and ruin it with this ugly plastic part, which could have easily been made by metal? I'm considering performing surgery on this thing.
I wanted an electric kettle without plastic inside or out and am very pleased with the quality, length of boiling time and durability of this product.
